summary: The image depicts a microscopic view of neurons within the brain, with specific focus on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChR). These receptors are identified by their pentameter structure and the presence of hexamezhonium, a compound known to interact with nAChRs. The image highlights the diverse subtypes of nAChRs and their potential role in various brain functions.
corrected_text: 1) Synopsis of Current Research: There are many drugs of abuse, each of which has a distinctive pharmacology. For example, stimulant drugs (eg,, amphetamine and caffeine) and depressant drugs (e.g, alcohol and barbiturates) differ in their subjective effects, but both types of drugs are abused. It has been demonstrated in animal studies that certain brain areas play relatively more important roles in the development and maintenance of behaviors related to the rewarding properties of drugs of abuse, Two important pathways are the mesolithic and mesocortical dopamine pathways, which emerge from the ventral segmental area of sal (VTA), Projection of the neurons of the via to the nucleus accumbent (mesolimbic) and to the prefrontal cortex (mesocortical) appear to be important for the expression of the rewarding properties of a wide variety of drugs of abuse. Most drugs of abuse increase newrotransmissfon through the mesolimbic-mesocortical sytems, either increasing activity of VIA neurons (e.g., nicotine, opiates, ethanol) or by augmenting the release of dopamine in the terminal areas (e.g., cocaine and amphetamine). Because the via is one important area for the mediation of drug-induced reward, the study of how various abused substances affect neurons of the VIA is a critical for the treatment of addiction. The overall goal of my research is to develop a better understanding of the physiology and pharmacology of central reward systems, In order to approach this goal, I have developed a brain slice preparation of the VIA suitable for intra- and extracellular recording, Putative dopamine containing neurons of the mesencephalon have been well characterized electrophysiologically in vivo; neurons in the brain slice appear similar to neurons studied in vivo, sea neurons fire spontaneously in a slow (0.5 - 5 Hz), regular pattem, We have examined the efforts of several drugs of abuse on this spontaneous activity. Among the agents we have examined are cocaine (Brodie and Dunwiddie, 1990) and ethyl alcohol (Brodie, et al., 1990), We are continuing our study of ethanol, by using intracellular recording in an attempt to determine the mechanism of action of ethanol-induced excitation of VIA neurons. ethanol appears to cause a slight depolarization, a decrease in the action potential amplitude, and a decrease in the amplitude of the afterhyperpolatization (Brodie and Shefner, 1989). Further experiments are planned to determine whether any of these effects underlies the ethanol-induced excitation of via neurons. We have also investigated the effects of nicotine on the spontaneous activity of VIA neurons @rodie, 1991), Nicotine excites VIA neurons ina concentration-dependent manner, via neurons possess an EC50 for nicotine-induced excitation of about 250 nM; therefore, VIA neurons are more sensitive to the excusatory effects of nicotine than many other central neurons. Furthermore, little desensitization to the effects of nicotine are seen at lower concentrations (less than. 1 uM) (Brodie, 1991). The response of via neurons to nicotine is blocked by hexamezhonium or mecamylamine, VIA neurons also possess pirenzepinesensitive muscarine cholinergic receptors (Brodie and Mueller, 1988; Lacey, et al, 1988), so studies of nicotine cholinergic receptors must be performed with specific nicotine agonists, and/or in the presence of muscarine cholinergic antagonists. With our preparation, a full range of concentrations of nicotine can be applied to the same via neuron, which would permit a more precise characterization of the specific receptor subtype involved in mediating nicotine-induced excitation of VIA neurons. 2) reseal 1d Goals of see Research Molecular biologists have identified a number of different subtypes of the nicotine cholinergic receptor. It is known that the nicotine cholinergic receptor is a pentameter formed from. 4 subunits: 2 subunits, and one each of B, y (or ) and 8. Recent studies from a number of laboratories indicate that pharmacological specificity is conferred by the and B subunits. Five forms of the subunit (a2 - 6) and four forms of the B subunit (82 - BS) are found in at brain, Different combinations of the various forms of these subunits constitute functionally different 1
